Award.AwardTitle: Mapping Pathways To Urbanism And Social Complexity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Tatsuya Murakami of Tulane University will conduct archaeological research on the origins and development of one of the first cities in Central Mexico. Once built, cities tend to grow in size and complexity, and it is observed that many modern cities keep attracting people from rural areas. However, urban formation is by no means a necessary consequence of population growth and/or technological, economic, and political development. Recent investigation has shown that there are many different forms of cities, and thus multiple pathways to urbanism. While some early cities were created as a result of the incentive of powerful individuals and groups, other cities were formed without a strong central authority. Understanding causes and consequences of early urbanism has great implications for reconsidering the current state of urban societies in historical and comparative perspectives and for better understanding the human nature. This study forms part of a long-term research program that explores how social distinctions (e.g., social inequality, division of labor) and social integration are simultaneously achieved and are constituted by different kinds of material culture. The project will provide an empirical basis for such endeavor and will serve to generate testable hypotheses.

Dr. Murakami, in collaboration with Mexican and Japanese scholars, will carry out surface reconnaissance, manual auger testing, and excavations of residential areas at the archaeological site of Tlalancaleca in the modern state of Puebla, which was one of the largest settlements during the Formative Period (800 BC-AD 200) in Central Mexico. The Central Mexican urban traditions during the later periods can be characterized by compact, high-density settlements, and cities such as Teotihuacan and Tenochtitlan served as seats of ruling elites. Investigation at Tlalancaleca will shed an important light on how these urban traditions were created in specific cultural and historical settings. Was the creation of the first city in Central Mexico an outcome of political centralization? Or was the early city an aggregate of more or less independent communities? To what extent were various individuals and groups integrated into a single urban community? To answer these significant questions, this study will examine diachronic changes in the extent of urban settlement, population size and density, neighborhood organization, and the extent of monumental construction. All these variables are closely associated with the nature of intra-urban communication, and their assessment will illuminate the nature and degree of social integration in terms of the relative role of actions of powerful individuals and groups as well as commoners. This study will specifically address the role of cooperation and collective action in the genesis and transformation of urban settlement. This project actively involves both undergraduate and graduate students from the US and Mexico for professional development and enhances international collaborations. Public outreach and the training of local people in archaeological practice are also an essential part of the project and will contribute to community development in a rural area of Mexico.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Tatsuya Murakami of Tulane University, in collaboration with Mexican and Japanese scholars, is investigating the development of ancient urban traditions in Central Mexico from the site of Tlalancaleca. Tlalancaleca is located in the modern state of Puebla, Mexico, and was one of the largest settlements in Central Mexico during the Formative Period (800 BC-AD 250). Dr. Murakami?s team has carried out surveys, manual auger testing, soil geochemical analysis, artifact analysis, and excavations of residential areas at Tlalancaleca to study its history and demonstrate how Central Mexican urban traditions were created in specific cultural and historical settings. A major topic to this end has been exploring how social distinctions (e.g., social inequality, division of labor) and social integration were simultaneously achieved and constituted via material culture at Tlalancaleca.

 

Using ceramic chronology, excavation data, and radiocarbon dating, Dr. Murakami and his team have created a general trajectory of urban transformation that occurred at Tlalancaleca between ca. 800 BC and AD 250 (Middle to Terminal Formative periods). Humans settled permanently at Tlalancaleca for the first time around 800 BC in the form of dispersed residential groups. They likely carried out ceremonial activities in a ditched palisade or woodhenge-like structure located apart from their residences. This is the first feature of its kind documented in Mesoamerica and so it requires further study to determine its functions with certainty. Around 650 BC, humans nucleated at Tlalancaleca, increasing its size to at least 80 ha in settled area and its population to 2,000-4,000 inhabitants. By the first century BC, Tlalancaleca reached 550 ha in area and harbored a population of 6,500-13,000 people. At this time, nine civic-ceremonial complexes, composed of pyramids and plazas, were built across the site and subsequently enlarged until the site?s abandonment around AD 250. These complexes do not form a central ceremonial precinct but are spatially dispersed across the site. They likely differed, therefore, in terms of their functions and the people they served.

 

Around AD 70, an eruption of the Popocatepetl volcano devastated southern areas of Central Mexico, yet archaeological evidence indicates that Tlalancaleca continued expanding after this date. Monumental construction projects, for example, accelerated at Tlalancaleca after the eruption and heightened civic-ceremonial activities were undertaken. This urban expansion during the Terminal Formative (100 BC-AD 250) entailed increasingly complex social interactions within the city, represented by the socio-spatial differentiations manifest in the multiple civic-ceremonial complexes distributed across the site. Most importantly, this trajectory places Tlalancaleca as a contemporary to the Teotihuacan state that formed around AD 200. This will require all scholars working in Central Mexico to reconsider urban transformations and state formation from a macroregional perspective.

 

Students from the US, Mexico and Japan have participated in all stages of the project. In particular, eight graduate students have participated from Tulane University, one graduate student from the Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, one graduate student from Tohoku University, Japan, and more than one dozen undergraduate students from the Universidad de las Americas Puebla. Students participation has ranged from surface collection and manual auger probes to excavations, ceramic analysis, and data management. This wide range of experiences has developed in students robust skillsets, which now support them in independent research projects of their own. Students also assist in preparing technical reports submitted to the Mexican government and papers presented at local and international conferences. Murakami and his team also give public talks and workshops for the local community of San Matias Tlalancaleca.
